node.title: 'There have been rumours': Why the next two years could decide the fate of Kim Jong Un
node.alt: Kim Jong Un in a black leather trench coat, with his hands in his pockets, walking through a snowy streets with men behind him
node.description: North Korea claims to have been COVID-free for the duration of the pandemic. But recent events south of the border could have major implications for the secretive nation and its enigmatic ruler.
node.content:
["The tension on the Korean peninsula has always been most palpable at the strip of land where these two nations meet: The heavily guarded\u00a0Demilitarised Zone (DMZ).\u00a0", "Before the pandemic, North and South Korean forces would stand face-to-face here, armed adversaries refusing to give an inch.\u00a0\u00a0", "But coronavirus has seen soldiers from one side of the conflict take a few steps back into their territory.\u00a0", "\"The [North Korean] soldiers still work there, but they don't come out of their buildings,\" said\u00a0Vice Admiral Stuart Mayer, an\u00a0Australian who is second in charge of the United Nation's Command which controls the area.\u00a0", "", "
The Joint Security Area is the only section of the Korean Demilitarised Zone where soldiers from the North and South can come into contact.\u00a0(ABC News: Mitch Denman Woolnough\u00a0)
", "The North Korean side of the border is unkempt, as\u00a0the maintenance crews won't risk coming into close contact with the south.", "What is really happening beyond the border is always a mystery.\u00a0", "\"North Korea constantly surprises. It's\u00a0called the hermit kingdom\u00a0for very good reason,\"\u00a0said\u00a0Vice Admiral Mayer.\u00a0", "But it's clear to everyone that\u00a0North Korea\u00a0cannot\u00a0risk an outbreak of COVID-19.\u00a0", "\"North Korea's COVID measures are extremely strict, beyond anything that we experience in democracies,\" he said.\u00a0", "While the North has claimed to be COVID-free for the duration of the pandemic, the past 18 months has taught us that this virus will always find a way.\u00a0", "And\u00a0recent events south of the border could have major implications for North Korea and its enigmatic ruler.\u00a0", "
South Korea is suddenly\u00a0in dire straits
", "South Korea has recently started easing its restrictions, pivoting to a new policy of learning to live with the virus.\u00a0", "But since then, the situation has rapidly deteriorated.\u00a0", "The\u00a0latest surge in South Korean cases has once again been triggered by a controversial\u00a0sect.\u00a0", "This time, a\u00a0cluster of infections spread from a little-known religious settlement led by a pastor who pokes his followers in the eyes to heal them.\u00a0", "", "
The latest surge of COVID-19\u00a0in South Korea is breaking daily infection records.\u00a0(ABC News: Mitch Denman Woolnough\u00a0)
", "South Korea\u00a0is now averaging about 4,000\u00a0cases a day. More worrying is the acute spike in serious cases.", "Despite nearly 80 per cent of South Koreans being fully vaccinated,\u00a0almost two-thirds\u00a0of ICU beds across the nation are full.", "If the virus creeps over the border into North Korea, the country is unlikely to cope.\u00a0", "With a decrepit medical system, it\u00a0slammed its borders shut to the world in early 2020.\u00a0", "While experts are sceptical of the regime's claim that they have\u00a0since been virus-free,\u00a0Rachel Minyoung Lee from the Stimson Centre said there are clues the situation is under control \u2014 for now.", "\"They continue to have large-scale gatherings, which tells me that the regime feels comfortable and confident about managing the situation,\" the North Korea watcher said.\u00a0", "But by keeping out the virus, they have also kept out vital supplies of fuel, which is necessary for food production.", "\"Definitely, the food situation is difficult. Kim Jong Un mentioned that directly,\" she said.\u00a0", "A reported exodus of the remaining foreign diplomats still in North Korea suggests the nation is continuing with its elimination strategy.\u00a0", "", "
North Korea watcher\u00a0Rachel Minyoung Lee says coronavirus is an opportunity and a threat for Kim Jong Un.\u00a0(ABC News: Mitch Denman Woolnough\u00a0)
", "Ms Lee said that suggests the \"COVID lockdown will be in place for a while longer\".", "\"That's why they're leaving. They don't know when the situation is going to end,\" she said.\u00a0", "North Korea has so far knocked back potential shipments of vaccine from the UN-backed COVAX facility and there are no signs it has struck a deal with its two most important partners, China and Russia.\u00a0", "\"They maybe have\u00a0trust issues with the Chinese vaccine and perhaps even the Russia vaccine,\" Ms Lee said.", "\"I think the other issue too, is whether it can get enough doses for the entire population.\"\u00a0", "While no-one knows for sure, intelligence suggests even Kim Jong Un himself may still be unvaccinated.\u00a0", "
The potential dangers for Kim Jong Un
", "Coronavirus has presented opportunities and potential threats to Kim Jong Un's power.", "Experts say the North Korean ruler has long believed his country is too reliant on its neighbour China.\u00a0", "With their shared border closed, he has been able to push a campaign of self-reliance.\u00a0", "", "
North Korean soldiers have retreated away from the DMZ, likely to avoid the spread of COVID-19.(ABC News: Mitch Denman Woolnough\u00a0)
", "\"He's a smart man\u00a0and he realises that it's not a sustainable model to be overly reliant on one country,\" Ms Lee said.\u00a0", "His recent dramatic weight loss led some analysts to wonder if\u00a0he was in ill health.\u00a0", "But Ms Less suspects he is\u00a0trying to consolidate his power\u00a0and stave off concerns about his longevity.\u00a0", "\"I think that was due to some strict diet regimen,\" said Ms Lee.", "\u201cHe's now on the same footing as [his grandfather] Kim Il Sung and [father] Kim Jong Il.\"\u00a0", "But other analysts aren't so certain Kim Jong Un is doing enough to maintain his grip on power.\u00a0", "\"There have been rumours Kim Jong Un's leadership could be re-evaluated in the next two years,\" said national security analyst Yun Ji-won from Sangmyung University.\u00a0\u00a0", "", "
Some analysts are interested to see what Kim Jong Un's sister Kim Yo Jong does in the next two years.\u00a0(AP: Jorge Silva)
", "She said there are even whispers\u00a0of a potential coup by his little sister, Kim Yo Jong.", "\"It's far-fetched,\" Ms Yun said.\u00a0"]
